sen.j: 元正天皇（げんしょうてんのう、天武天皇8年（680年） - 天平20年4月21日 (旧暦)（748年5月22日））は奈良時代の第44代天皇で女帝（在位：霊亀元年9月2日 (旧暦)（715年10月3日） - 養老8年2月4日 (旧暦)（724年3月3日））。
sen.e: Empress Gensho (679 – May 26, 748; reign: October 7, 715 – March 7, 724) was the forty-fourth imperial ruler (empress regnant) of Japan in Nara period.
sen.cmt: 天武天皇8年は時期によって679年または680年になるようですが、元日にあわせて679年として訳出しています。
sen.e: Empress Gensho (680 – May 22, 748) was the forty-fourth emperor of Japan (empress regnant who reigned from October 3, 715, to March 3, 724), who lived in the Nara period.
Empress Gensho (680 – May 22, 748) was the forty-fourth emperor of Japan (empress regnant who reigned from October 3, 715, to March 3, 724), who lived in the Nara period.

sen.j: 父は天武天皇と持統天皇の子である草壁皇子、母は元明天皇。
sen.e: Her father was Prince Kusakabe, the son of the Emperor Tenmu and the Empress Jito; and her mother was the Empress Genmei.
Her father was Kusakabe no miko (the term miko refers to imperial prince), a son of Emperor Tenmu and Empress Jito, and her mother was Empress Genmei.

sen.e: Her name before enthronement was Hitaka no himemiko.

sen.e: Her Japanese-style posthumous name is Yamatonekotamamizukiyotarashihime no Sumeramikoto.

sen.j: 日本の女性天皇としては5人目であるが、それまでの女帝が皇后や皇太子妃であったのに対し、結婚経験は無く、独身で即位した初めての女性天皇である。
sen.e: She is the fifth empress regnant in Japan, and the first empress who ascended the throne before marriage, while the empresses before her were wives of emperors or princes.

She is the fifth empress regnant in Japan, who, in contrast to the previous empresses having been empresses consort or crown princesses, had never gotten married and was single at enthronement, thus being the first virgin empress of Japan.
sen.cmt: 言い回し、用語、曖昧さ回避、文脈調整
sen.e: She is the fifth empress regnant in Japan, who, in contrast to the previous empresses having been empresses consort or crown princesses, had never gotten married and was single at enthronement, thus being the first virgin empress of Japan.

sen.j: また、歴代天皇の中で唯一、母から娘へと女系での継承が行われた天皇でもある（ただし、父親は男系男子の皇族である草壁皇子であるため、男系の血統は維持されている）。
sen.e: She is also the first empress who succeeded to the throne from her mother, that is, from the maternal side of the family (however, her father Prince Kusakabe was a male through an imperial line of males, so the male blood line was maintained).

In addition, she was the only emperor of Japan, who experienced succession to the throne through the maternal line, from mother to daughter (N.B. her father Kusakabe no miko was a male imperial family member descended through a line of males, and therefore the male imperial blood line was maintained).

In addition, she was the only emperor of Japan, who experienced succession to the throne through the maternal line, from mother to daughter (N.B. her father Kusakabe no miko was a male imperial family member descended through a line of males, and therefore the male imperial blood line was maintained).
